abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            with a likely sustainability. The physical targets of
            reconstruction were met - in many cases, exceeded
            expectations - within the original cost estimates, except
            for increases in amounts expended under specific components,
            which were either due to reallocations from other
            components, or to changes in composition of investment. The
            key lessons suggest that complexity in emergency operations
            may not need to be entirely avoided, as long as the Bank is
            prepared to support the Borrower through proactive, and
            staff-intensive involvement during project preparation, and
            subsequently during implementation, ensuring adequate
            technical assistance, and financing, either under the loan,
            or preferably, through grant financing from donors. The Bank
            should promptly respond to project preparation needs, to
            avoid delays which can change the composition of assistance.
            Changing circumstances, particularly in operations under
            harsh political environments, call for adjustments within
            components, thus requiring flexibility, and timeliness to
            ensure an effective assistance. Since time is of the essence
            in emergency operations, special attention should be given
            to defining procurement arrangements, and capacity building,
            thus a strong preparation would ease the burden of
            correcting deficiencies in the subsequent supervision stages.
